''[[Pont Abraham services]]'' |- | colspan="5" style="text-align:center;"|DataArea 3 Driver Location Signs (map) – Highway Authority, 2009Driver Location Signs, M5 J18-11, M4 J22-15 (map) Highway Authority 2009{{cite web |url=http://www.trafficengland.com/map.aspx |title=Traffic England Live Traffic Condition Map ''(selected Popups)'' |publisher=Highways Agency |accessdate=5 November 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120210221222/http://www.trafficengland.com/map.aspx |archivedate=10 February 2012 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.traffic-wales.com/resources |title=Resources |quote=Select Telephone & marker post locations. |publisher=Traffig Cymru/Traffic Wales |accessdate=22 August 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903120036/http://www.traffic-wales.com/resources |archivedate= 3 September 2011 |df= }} from [[Driver location signs|driver location signs and location marker posts]] are used to provide distance and carriageway identification information. Where a junction spans several hundred metres and the data is available, both the start and finish values for the junction are shown. |- {{jctbtm|keys=incomplete,toll}} ;Coordinate list ==Incidents and accidents== * In June 1984 a crash near [[Maidenhead]] resulted in 13 deaths.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-187995/Death-toll-British-roads.html|title=Death toll on British roads|work=Daily Mail|quote=13 died in a crash on the M4 near Maidenhead, Berks, in June 1984.|location=London}} * In March 1991 ten people died in a [[1991 M4 Motorway crash|series of crashes in 1991]] involving 51 vehicles near [[Hungerford]]. * In May 1995 a coach carrying [[Royal British Legion]] members left the road close to the Severn Bridge, resulting in 10 deaths. * In April 1998, drummer [[Cozy Powell]] died following a car accident on the M4 near Bristol. * In July 2002, [[Gus Dudgeon]], a music producer known for his work with [[Elton John]], and his wife died when the car he was driving veered off the M4 between Reading and Maidenhead. The inquest recorded a verdict of accidental death.{{cite news | title=Record producer dies in crash | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/2144817.stm | publisher=[[BBC News Online]] | accessdate=13 February 2015 | date=22 July 2002}} * In July 2011 a lorry fire in the [[Brynglas Tunnels]] closed the motorway.{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-14288312 | title = Traffic chaos after M4 Brynglas tunnel lorry blaze| date = 26 July 2011 | accessdate = 9 April 2013 | publisher = BBC News}} Although there were no injuries and no deaths, one tunnel remained closed and a contraflow system was in place in the remaining tunnel for about one month, causing major travel delays.{{Cite web |url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-south-east-wales-14344483 | title = M4 tunnel fire: Brynglas tunnel reopens| date = 29 July 2011 | accessdate = 9 April 2013 | publisher = BBC News}}{{Cite web | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-wales-14318891 | title = M4 tunnel fire sparks relief road debate | date = 27 July 2011 | accessdate = 9 April 2013 | publisher = BBC News}} ==See also== revision.comment: /* Supporting features and availability */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: BMC systems biology → BMC Systems Biology using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text: The '''MIRIAM Registry''', a by-product of the [[MIRIAM]] Guidelines, is a database of namespaces and associated information that is used in the creation of [[URI|uniform resource identifiers]]. It contains the set of community-approved namespaces for databases and resources serving, primarily, the biological sciences domain. These shared namespaces, when combined with 'data collection' identifiers, can be used to create globally unique identifiers for knowledge held in data repositories. For more information on the use of URIs to annotate models, see the specification of [http://sbml.org/wiki/ SBML Level 2 Version 2] (and above). A 'data collection' is defined as a set of data which is generated by a provider. A 'resource' is defined as a distributor of that data. Such a description allows numerous resources to be associated with a single collection, allowing accurate representation of how biological information is available on the World Wide Web; often the same information, from a single data collection, may be mirrored by different resources, or the core information may be supplemented with other data. [[Image:Registry Gene Ontology entry.png|thumb|Example of an entry stored in the MIRIAM Registry]] * data collection name: Gene Ontology * data collection identifier: MIR:00000022 * data collection synonyms: GO * data collection identifier pattern: ^GO:\d{7}$ * data collection namespace: urn:miriam:obo.go * data collection 'Root URL': http://identifiers.org/obo.go/ * data collection 'Root URN': urn:miriam:obo.go: * collection resources: ** resource #1 *** resource identifier: MIR:00100012 *** resource location website: http://www.ebi.ac.uk/ego/ *** resource access URL (tokenised): http://www.ebi.ac.uk/ego/DisplayGoTerm?selected=$1 *** resource Description: QuickGO (Gene Ontology browser) *** resource institution: European Bioinformatics Institute, United Kingdom ** resource #2 *** [...] The MIRIAM Registry is a curated resource, which is freely available and open to all. Submissions for new collections can be made through the website.{{cite web|url=http://www.ebi.ac.uk/miriam/main/mdb?section=submit |title=New Collection Submission page |publisher=Ebi.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-10-09}} == Identifiers using the MIRIAM system == The MIRIAM Guidelines require the use of uniform resource identifiers in the annotation of model components. These are created using the shared list of namespaces defined in the MIRIAM Registry. ===MIRIAM URIs=== Using the namespaces defined in the MIRIAM Registry, it is possible to create identifiers in both a URN and a URL forms. This requires a unique collection-specific identifier, as well as a namespace to globally constrain the information space. Both the namespace and the root of each URI form are given for each data collection in the Registry. It should be noted that both forms are derived from the same namespace. For example: * urn form: urn:miriam:pubmed:16333295 * url form: http://identifiers.org/pubmed/16333295 In this example, the collection-specific identifier is 16333295, and the namespace is pubmed. The URN form of identifiers requires the use of Web Services or programmatic means to access the referenced record. This means that one cannot simply put the URN form into a browser window and arrive at the referenced information. The URL form is directly resolvable, and relies on a resolving layer provided by [[Identifiers.org]]. ===Supporting features and availability=== To enable efficient use of the MIRIAM Registry and the rapid adoption of the annotation scheme, a number of supporting features are provided.{{cite journal |doi=10.1186/1752-0509-1-58 |title=MIRIAM Resources: Tools to generate and resolve robust cross-references in Systems Biology |year=2007 |last1=Laibe |first1=Camille |last2=Le Novère |first2=Nicolas |journal=BMC Systems Biology |volume=1 |page=58 |pmid=18078503 |pmc=2259379}} These include [[Web Services]], a website interface{{cite web|url=http://www.ebi.ac.uk/miriam/ |title=MIRIAM Resources Website |publisher=Ebi.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-10-09}} to access the Registry itself, and a Java library{{cite journal |doi=10.1093/bib/bbp056 |title=BioModels.net Web Services, a free and integrated toolkit for computational modelling software |year=2009 |last1=Li |first1=C. |last2=Courtot |first2=M. |last3=Le Novere |first3=N. |last4=Laibe |first4=C. |journal=Briefings in Bioinformatics |volume=11 |issue=3 |pages=270–7 |pmid=19939940 |pmc=2913671}} The MIRIAM Registry is developed by the Proteomics Services Team at the [[European Bioinformatics Institute]]. The source code for the entire project, including supporting features, is available from [[SourceForge.net]].{{cite web|url=http://sourceforge.net/projects/miriam/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-10-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120510124143/http://sourceforge.net/projects/miriam/ |archivedate=2012-05-10 |df= }} MIRIAM project on SourceForge.net{{psc|date=February 2012}} The '''MIRIAM Registry''' is used by several worldwide projects such as [[BioModels Database]],{{cite journal |pmid=20587024 |year=2010 |last1=Li |first1=C |last2=Donizelli |first2=M |last3=Rodriguez |first3=N |last4=Dharuri |first4=H |last5=Endler |first5=L |last6=Chelliah |first6=V |last7=Li |first7=L |last8=He |first8=E |last9=Henry |first9=A |last10=Stefan |first10=Melanie I |last11=Snoep |first11=Jacky L |last12=Hucka |first12=Michael |last13=Le Novère |first13=Nicolas |last14=Laibe |first14=Camille |title=BioModels Database: An enhanced, curated and annotated resource for published quantitative kinetic models |volume=4 |page=92 |doi=10.1186/1752-0509-4-92 |pmc=2909940 |journal=BMC Systems Biology}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ebi.ac.uk/biomodels/ |title=BioModels Database Website |publisher=Ebi.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-10-09}} SABIO-RK,{{cite web|author=SDBV |url=http://sabio.villa-bosch.de/ |title=SABIO-Reaction Kinetics Database Virtual Cell |publisher=Sabio.villa-bosch.de |date= |accessdate=2012-10-09}} COPASI,{{cite web|url=http://www.copasi.org/ |title=Complex Pathway Simulator and SBMLeditor |publisher=Copasi.org |date= |accessdate=2012-10-09}} A more thorough listing can be found on the website.{{cite web|url=http://www.ebi.ac.uk/miriam/main/mdb?section=use |title=MIRIAM Usage |publisher=Ebi.ac.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-10-09}} ==See also== * [[Minimum information standards]] * [[MIRIAM]] * [[Identifiers.org]] * [[Metadata standards]] * [[Computational systems biology]] * [[BioModels Database]] * [[SBML]] * [[CellML]] == References == {{Reflist}} [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Bioinformatics]] [[Category:Systems biology]]

revision.text:
[[Image:NaplesDioscuridesMandrake.jpg|thumb|Folio 90v of the 'Naples Dioscurides' (a manuscript of ''[[De Materia Medica (Dioscorides)|De Materia Medica]]'') with illustrations of the [[Mandrake (plant)|Mandrake]]]] The '''Naples Dioscurides''' in the [[Biblioteca Nazionale Vittorio Emanuele III|Biblioteca Nazionale]], [[Naples]] (MS Suppl. gr. 28), is an [[illuminated manuscript]] early 7th-century [[Greek language|Greek]] [[herbal]]. The book has 172 folios and a page size of 29.7 x 14 cm (11 11/16 x 5 1/2 inches) and the text is a redaction of ''[[De Materia Medica (Dioscorides)|De Materia Medica]]'' by the 1st century Greek military physician [[Dioscorides]], with descriptions of plants and their medicinal uses.<ref>Weitzmann, 206</ref> Unlike ''De Materia Medica'', the text is arranged alphabetically by plant. The [[codex]] derives independently<ref>David H. Wright, "''Traditio'' and ''Inventio'' in Iconographic Transmission," Eighth Byzantine Studies Conference, Chicago 1982</ref> from the same model as the [[Vienna Dioscurides]], which was created ca. 512 for a Byzantine princess, but differs from it significantly: <ref>{{Cite web | last = Dioscorides | first = Pedanius | title = Of Medical Substances - De materia medica - Dioscurides Neapolitanus | work = World Digital Library | accessdate = 2014-06-20 | url = http://www.wdl.org/en/item/10690 }}</ref> though the illustrations follow the same inferred model, they are rendered more naturalistically in the Naples Dioscurides. Additionally, in the Naples manuscript, the illustrations occupy the top half of each folio, rather than being full page miniatures as in the Vienna Dioscurides. The plant descriptions are recorded below the illustration in two or three rather narrow columns, recalling the arrangement the earliest [[scroll]] version of the work would have had, before the [[codex]] form became near-universal. The script is somewhat rough and uneven, and the painting style of the miniatures less precise and naturalistic than the Vienna manuscript, indicating a certain falling-off in standards.<ref>Weitzmann, 206-207</ref> The [[Paleography|style of Greek script]] used in the manuscript indicates that it was probably written in Byzantine-ruled southern [[Italy]], where ancient Greek cultural traditions remained strong, although it is not known exactly where it was produced.
Marginal notes indicate that the manuscript had contact with the [[Schola Medica Salernitana|medical school at Salerno]] in the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries.
A luxurious facsimile has been published by Salerno Editrice, Rome, in collaboration with Akademische Druck of Graz, Austria, publishers of a comparable facsimile of the Vienna Dioscurides.
== Notes == {{reflist}}
*{{Cite web | last = Dioscorides | first = Pedanius | title = De materia medica - Dioscurides Neapolitanus | work = World Digital Library | accessdate = 2014-06-20 | url = http://www.wdl.org/en/item/10690 }}
==References== *Crinelli, Lorenzo. ''Treasures from Italy's Great Libraries''. New York, The Vendome Press, 1997. *[[Kurt Weitzmann|Weitzmann, Kurt]], ed., ''[http://libmma.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p15324coll10/id/156533 Age of spirituality: late antique and early Christian art, third to seventh century]'', no. 180, 1979, [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York, {{ISBN|9780870991790}}; full text available online from The Metropolitan Museum of Art Libraries
[[Category:7th-century illuminated manuscripts]] [[Category:Biology books]] [[Category:Scientific illuminated manuscripts]]

page.title: National Addiction and HIV Data Archive Program

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=April 2013}}
The '''National Addiction and HIV Data Archive Program''' ('''NAHDAP''') is a [[Digital library|repository]] of drug abuse and [[HIV/AIDS research]] data primarily including social science and behavioral data.<ref>''Addiction,'' 106, 1708-1710</ref> NAHDAP’s mission is to bring the power of science to bear on drug abuse and addiction by supporting research across a wide range of disciplines and ensuring the rapid and effective dissemination and use of the results of that research to improve prevention, treatment and policy.
==Description==
NAHDAP is a program within the [[ICPSR|Inter-university Consortium for Political and Social Research (ICPSR)]], a unit in the Institute for Social Research (ISR) at the [[University of Michigan]]. NAHDAP's staff consists of professional researchers, data archivists and technicians working together to obtain, process, distribute, and promote amongst social science researchers [[Data sharing|sharing of data]] relevant to drug addiction and HIV.
NAHDAP is a project of the [[National Institute on Drug Abuse]], part of the [[National Institutes of Health]]. The [http://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/NAHDAP/ NAHDAP Web site] launched in June 2010 and offers a library of electronic data and [[citations]] to publications based on those data. NAHDAP provides technical assistance and resources to investigators to facilitate preparing their data for archiving so that they can be easily and effectively archived at project completion. NAHDAP also provides technical assistance to users of the data sets, including workshops and webinars, to train analysts in the unique characteristics of selected datasets, in [[Quantitative research|quantitative method]]s, and in the utility of analyzing [[Secondary data analysis|secondary data]] for the [[Reproduceability|reproduction of original research findings]] and addressing new research questions on major issues of social and behavioral sciences and public policy.
==External links== * [http://www.icpsr.umich.edu/icpsrweb/NAHDAP/ NAHDAP Web site] * [http://www.drugabuse.gov National Institute on Drug Abuse] * [http://www.drugabuse.gov/about-nida/organization/divisions/division-epidemiology-services-prevention-research-despr/research-resources NIDA Division of Epidemiology, Services and Services and Prevention Research -- Research Resources page] * [http://www.nih.gov National Institutes of Health] * [http://grants.nih.gov/grants/policy/data_sharing/ NIH Data Sharing Policy] * [http://grants.nih.gov/grants/guide/notice-files/NOT-OD-03-032.html NIH Data Sharing Policy and Implementation Guidance] * [http://grants.nih.gov/grants/guide/notice-files/NOT-OD-03-032.html Final NIH Statement on Sharing Research Data]
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Social research]]

{{distinguish|The Nautilus (magazine)|The Nautilus (journal)}} {{Infobox magazine | title = Nautilus | logo = | logo_size = <!-- default is 180px --> | image_file = <!-- cover.jpg (omit the "file:" prefix) --> | image_size = <!-- default is 180px --> | image_alt = | image_caption = | editor = John Steele | editor_title = Editorial Director | editor2 = Michael Segal | editor_title2 = Founding Editor in Chief | previous_editor = | staff_writer = | photographer = | category = Science | frequency = Bi-monthly | format = | circulation = | publisher = John Steele | paid_circulation = | unpaid_circulation = | circulation_year = | total_circulation = | founder = John Steele | founded = | firstdate = {{Start date and age|2013|04}} | finaldate = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | finalnumber = | company = NautilusThink Inc. | country = United States | based = New York | language = English | website = {{URL|http://nautil.us}} | issn = 2372-1766 | oclc = }}
'''''Nautilus''''' is an online and print science magazine that "combines the sciences, culture and philosophy into a single story."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nautil.us/about| title=About ''Nautilus''| date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It publishes one "issue" on a selected topic each month on its website, releasing one "chapter" each Thursday.<ref>{{Cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/07/science/a-glossy-science-magazine-or-living-fossil.html|title=A Magazine or a Living Fossil?|newspaper=The New York Times|date=6 May 2013|accessdate=5 March 2015|author=Dennis Overbye}}</ref> Issue topics have included human uniqueness, time, uncertainty, genius, mergers & acquisitions, and feedback.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nautil.us/issues|title=''Nautilus'' Issue Library|date=2018-11-05}}</ref> ''Nautilus'' also publishes a print edition six times a year,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://shop.nautil.us/nautilus-print-edition/|title=Nautilus Print Magazine information}}</ref> and a daily blog called Facts So Romantic.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://nautil.us/blog|title=Facts So Romantic homepage|date=2018-11-05}}</ref> It makes regular use of original commissioned illustration to accompany its stories. The headquarters are in New York, NY.
==Reception==
In ''Nautilus''' launch year (2013), it was cited as one of [[Library Journal]]'s Ten Best New Magazines Launched;<ref>{{cite web | url=http://reviews.libraryjournal.com/2014/04/best-of/magazine-recovery-best-magazines-2013/ | title=Magazine Recovery / Best Magazines 2013 | work=[[Library Journal]] | date=16 April 2014 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | author=Steve Black}}</ref> was named one of the World's Best-Designed news sites by the [[Society for News Design]];<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.snd.org/2014/03/snd35-worlds-best-digital-design/ | title=SND35: Judges name Nautilus, WNYC, Al Jazeera and NYT World's Best-Designed | work=[[Society for News Design]] | date=27 March 2014 | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> received an honorary mention as one of RealClearScience's top science news sites;<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.realclearscience.com/lists/top_10_science_sites/honorable_mentions.html | title=Top 10 Science News Sites Honorable Mentions | work=RealClearScience | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> and received three awards from FOLIO: magazine, including Best Consumer Website and Best Full Issue.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.foliomag.com/2013/recapping-2013-eddie-ozzie-awards | title=Recapping The 2013 Eddie & Ozzie Awards | work=FOLIO: | date=5 December 2013 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | author=Caysey Welton}}</ref>
In 2014, the magazine won a [[Webby Award]] for best science website<ref>{{cite web | url=http://pv.webbyawards.com/2014/web/general-website/science | title=Science 2014 | publisher=[[Webby Award | Webby Award website]] | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> and was nominated for two others;<ref>{{cite web | url=http://pv.webbyawards.com/2014/web/website-features-and-design/best-visual-design-aesthetic | title=Best Visual Design | publisher=[[Webby award|Webby Award website]] | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://pv.webbyawards.com/2014/web/website-features-and-design/best-navigationstructure | title=Best Navigation/Structure | publisher=[[Webby award|Webby Award website]] | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> had two stories selected to be included in 2014 edition of [[The Best American Science and Nature Writing]];<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.hmhco.com/shop/general-interest/best-american/best-american-2014/best-american-science-nature-writing/contents | title=Best American Science and Nature Writing 2014 / Table of Contents | publisher=[[Houghton Mifflin Harcourt]] | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> won a FOLIO award for Best Standalone Digital Consumer Magazine; and was nominated for two Webby Awards.
In 2015, ''Nautilus'' won two [[National Magazine Awards]] (aka "Ellies"), for General Excellence (Literature, Science and Politics Magazines) and Best Website.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.magazine.org/industry-news/press-releases/asme-press-releases/asme/national-magazine-awards-2015-winners | title=National Magazine Awards 2015 Winners Announced | publisher=[[American Society of Magazine Editors]] | date= 3 February 2015 | accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref> It is the only magazine to have won multiple Ellies in its first year of eligibility. It also had one story included in the 2015 edition of The Best American Science and Nature Writing, and another story win a AAAS Kavli Science Journalism Award. RealClearScience again named it a top-10 science website.
In 2016, ''Nautilus'' had one story included in the 2016 edition of The Best American Science and Nature Writing; won an American Society of Magazine Editor's Award for Best Style and Design of a cover; and was nominated for a Webby Award.
In 2017, ''Nautilus'' had three stories selected for inclusion in the 2017 edition of The Best American Science and Nature Writing; had one piece win a AAAS Kavli Science Journalism Award; and was a Webby Award Nominee for Best Editorial Writing.
Over a dozen ''Nautilus'' illustrations have been recognized by American Illustration, Spectrum, and the Society of Illustrators.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://nautil.us/awards-and-press | title=Nautilus Awards and Press| date=2018-11-05}}</ref>
==Contributors==
Since the magazine's launch in April 2013, contributors have included scientists [[Peter Ward (paleontologist)|Peter Douglas Ward]], [[Caleb Scharf]], [[Gary Marcus]], [[Robert Sapolsky]], [[David Deutsch]], [[Lisa Kaltenegger]], [[Jim Davies (cognitive scientist)]], [[Laura Mersini-Houghton]], [[Ian Tattersall]], [[Max Tegmark]], [[Julian Barbour]], [[Scott Aaronson]], [[Steve Hsu]], [[Martin Rees]], [[Helen Fisher (anthropologist)]] and [[Leonard Mlodinow]]; and writer/journalists [[Christian H. Cooper]], [[Ayaan Hirsi Ali]], [[Amir Aczel]], [[Nicholas G. Carr|Nicholas Carr]], [[Carl Zimmer]], [[B.J. Novak]], [[Philip Ball]], [[Kitty Ferguson]], [[Jill Neimark]], [[Alan Lightman]], [[Tom Vanderbilt]], and [[George Musser]].
[[Cormac McCarthy]] made his non-fiction writing debut in Nautilus on 20 April 2017 with an article entitled The Kekulé Problem.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=McCarthy|first=Cormac|date=20 April 2017|title=The Kekulé Problem|url=http://nautil.us/issue/47/consciousness/the-kekul-problem|journal=Nautilus|volume=|pages=}}</ref>
==Name==
The word "nautilus" has a number of meanings that are referred to in the title of the magazine. "'The nautilus is so steeped in math and myth and story, from [[Nautilus (Verne)|Verne]] to the [[Golden ratio#Disputed observations|Golden Mean]] to the [[nautilus|spectacular sea creature]] itself,' [''Nautilus'' publisher John] Steele said, 'that it seemed a fitting namesake for the idea of connecting and illuminating science.'"<ref>{{Cite news | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/05/07/science/a-glossy-science-magazine-or-living-fossil.html | title=A Magazine or a Living Fossil? | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=6 May 2013 | accessdate=5 March 2015 | author=Dennis Overbye}}</ref>
== Controversy == On 13 December 2017, twenty of ''Nautilus''<nowiki/>' freelance writers published "An Open Letter from Freelancers at Nautilus Magazine"<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nwu.org/an-open-letter-from-freelancers-at-nautilus-magazine/|title=An Open Letter from Freelancers at Nautilus Magazine|last1=Jessica|first1=Seigel|last2=and 19 others|website=National Writers Union|publisher=National Writers Union|accessdate=13 December 2017}}</ref> in the [[National Writers Union]], alleging that the company was in arrears to them for $50,000 for unpaid work. They announced that ten of them had joined the NWU in order "to pursue a group non-payment grievance with legal action if necessary". On 15 December 2017, the ''Nautilus'' Publisher, John Steele, published a reply explaining the magazine's financial situation and taking responsibility for the late payments.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Steele|first=John|title=A Letter from the Publisher of Nautilus|url=http://nautil.us/blog/a-letter-from-the-publisher-of-nautilus|journal=Nautilus|date=2017-12-15}}</ref> On February 1, 2018, the National Writers Union announced it had reached a settlement with Steele.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://splinternews.com/a-little-reminder-of-why-media-unions-matter-1822624549|title=A Little Reminder of Why Media Unions Matter|last=Uberti|first=David|work=Splinter|access-date=2018-02-01|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Partnerships==
On March 20 2018, Nautilus announced a marketing partnership with Kalmbach Media, publisher of ''Discover'' and ''Astronomy'' Magazines.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kalmbach.com/2018/03/20/kalmbach-media-announces-marketing-partnership-with-nautilus-magazine/|title=Kalmbach Media announces marketing partnership with Nautilus magazine|work=Kalmbach Media|access-date=2018-03-23|language=en-US}}</ref> At the time of the partnership, the three magazines had a combined reach of 10 million users.
==References== {{Reflist|33em}}
== External links == * {{official website|http://nautil.us}}

{{EngvarB|date=October 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = [[Honorary degree|Dr]] | name = Nazia Khanum | honorific_suffix = [[Officer of the British Empire|OBE]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] | image = | alt = | caption = | native_name = নাজিয়া খানম | native_name_lang = bn | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1943}} | birth_place = [[Barisal]], [[Bengal Presidency]] (now [[Bangladesh]]), [[Presidencies and provinces of British India|British India]] | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | residence = [[Luton]], [[Bedfordshire]], [[England]] | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | education = BA and MA political science, PhD history | alma_mater = [[University of Dhaka]]
[[School of Oriental and African Studies]] | occupation = [[Management consulting|Management consultant]], researcher, [[Academia|academic]], [[Activism|social activist]] | years_active = 1983–present | title = Director of Equality in Diversity, non-executive director for [[National Health Service|NHS]] Luton | spouse = David Cheesman | children = 1 }} '''Nazia Khanum''', [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]], [[Deputy Lieutenant|DL]] ({{lang-bn|নাজিয়া খানম}}; born 1943) is a [[Bangladesh]]i-born [[United Kingdom|British]] [[Management consulting|management consultant]], researcher, Director of Equality in Diversity, non-executive director for [[National Health Service|NHS]] Luton and chair of various voluntary community organisations. ==Early life== Khanum was born in [[Barisal]], [[Partition of Bengal (1905)|Partition of Bengal]] (now [[Bangladesh]]), [[Presidencies and provinces of British India|British India]]. Her exact date of birth is unknown because during that period birth certificates were not given unless they were specifically requested. She was named by her father who died when she was very young. She moved with her family to Charfassion, [[Dhaka]] where she was brought up.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cu1W6Eo34Nc|title=Nazia Khanum|publisher=Luton Voices|date=8 June 2010|accessdate=1 December 2012}}{{cite web|url=http://www.lutonculture.com/community-projects/past-projects/luton-voices/volunteers/|title=Interviewees|publisher=Luton Culture|year=2010|accessdate=1 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004213310/http://www.lutonculture.com/community-projects/past-projects/luton-voices/volunteers/|archivedate=4 October 2013|df=dmy-all}} In the early 1980s, she brought her family to [[Luton]], [[Bedfordshire]], [[England]].{{cite news |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/threecounties/senseofplace/leap_of_faith.shtml |title=Leap of Faith |work=BBC News |date=February 2002 |accessdate=1 December 2012}} ==Education and career== Khanum has an BA and MA in political science from the [[University of Dhaka]], and a PhD in history from the [[School of Oriental and African Studies]], [[University of London]].{{cite book |last1=Karim |first1=Mohammed Abdul |last2=Karim |first2=Shahadoth |date=October 2011 |title=British Bangladeshi Who's Who |url=http://www.bbwhoswho.co.uk/images/who_%20who_2011.pdf |publisher=British Bangla Media Group |page=75 |isbn= |accessdate=1 December 2012}} She worked over a long period as a lecturer and later as an assistant professor in [[Eden Girls' College, Bangladesh|Eden Girls' College]] and the [[University of Dhaka]] in Bangladesh.{{cite web |url=http://www.equalbutdifferent.org.uk/pages/expertise_4.htm |title=Community Cohesion |website=Equal But Different |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304044007/http://www.equalbutdifferent.org.uk/pages/expertise_4.htm |archive-date=4 March 2016 |accessdate=1 December 2012}} In 1996, Khanum set up an independent international equal opportunities/diversity management, research and training consultancy. She is a non-executive director for NHS Luton.{{cite web |url=http://bbpower-inspiration.com/women/ |title=Women |website=British Bangladeshi Power & Inspiration 100 |date=January 2012 |accessdate=1 December 2012}} Since 1983, Khanum has been involved in community empowerment through her work with diverse communities, across the United Kingdom to promote their development and empowerment. She has extensive senior management experience with five English local authorities (Ealing, Tower Hamlets, Bedfordshire, GLC and ILEA).{{cite web |url=http://www.socialwork2000.co.uk/Forced_Marriage.pdf|title=Forced Marriage, Family Cohesion and Community Engagement|publisher=Social Work 2000|date=22 May 2008|accessdate=1 December 2012}} She is on the boards of several key decision-making and community-empowerment organisations, including: non-executive director of Luton Primary Care Trust.{{cite web |url=http://www.equalityindiversity.com/id5.html |title=Our Directors |publisher=Equality in Diversity |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140925090511/http://equalityindiversity.com/id5.html |archive-date=25 September 2014 |accessdate=1 December 2012}} She chairs several community groups in Luton{{cite news |last=Saner |first=Emine |date=14 March 2008 |title=The Invisibles |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/14/race.gender |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=1 December 2012}} She is on the boards of several key decision-making and community-empowerment organisations, including: non-executive director of Luton Primary Care Trust, member of the corporation and governor of [[Luton Sixth Form College]].{{cite web |url=http://old.lutonsfc.ac.uk/lutonhome/About/General/Governors.html |title=Governors |publisher=Luton Sixth form College |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225174307/http://old.lutonsfc.ac.uk/lutonhome/About/General/Governors.html |archive-date=25 December 2014 |accessdate=1 December 2012}} Chair of Luton All-Women's Centre, Luton Multi-Cultural Women's Coalition, including Luton Bangladesh Helping Hand{{cite news |last= |first= |url=http://www.eastlondonnews.com/star-studded-fund-raising-event-by-luton-bangladesh-helping-hand/|title=Star-studded fund-raising event by Luton Bangladesh Helping Hand |location=London |newspaper=East London News|date=27 July 2011 |accessdate=1 December 2012}} and Purbachal – the Eastern Sky. She is a member of the Government's Muslim Women's Advisory Group and a government equality ambassador for the Eastern Region. Khanum was a government adviser.{{cite news |last1=Riches |first1=Chris |last2=Lee |first2=Adrian |date=4 August 2012 |title=Killed For Trying To Be Normal|url=http://www.express.co.uk/posts/view/337481/Killed-for-trying-to-be-normal |newspaper=[[Daily Express]] |accessdate=1 December 2012}} on issues relating to ethnic minorities.{{cite news |last=Suroor |first=Hasan |date=20 March 2008 |title=Focus on forced marriages among Asian communities in the U.K. |url=http://www.hindu.com/2008/03/20/stories/2008032050841100.htm |location=India |newspaper=[[The Hindu]] |accessdate=1 December 2012}} In 2006, Khanum began a research study, for the [[Home Office]] and [[Metropolitan Police Service]], of forced marriage in Luton.{{cite news |title=Forced marriage problems revealed |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/beds/bucks/herts/7289421.stm |work=BBC News |date=11 March 2008 |accessdate=1 December 2012}} Published in March 2008, the study found that support organisations in Luton were approached with enquiries about forced marriage more than 300 times each year.{{cite news |last=Cunniffe |first=Jessica |date=9 March 2008 |title=Breadth of forced marriages exposed |url=http://www.luton-dunstable.co.uk/News/Breadth-of-forced-marriages-exposed.htm?id=262425 |location=Luton |publisher=''Luton & Dunstable'' |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004214303/http://www.luton-dunstable.co.uk/News/Breadth-of-forced-marriages-exposed.htm?id=262425 |archive-date=4 October 2013 |accessdate=1 December 2012}}{{cite news |last=Cunniffe |first=Jessica |url=http://www.luton-dunstable.co.uk/News/Seeking-way-to-end-forced-marriages.htm |title=Seeking way to end forced marriages |publisher=''Luton on Sunday'' |date=25 May 2008 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131004215808/http://www.luton-dunstable.co.uk/News/Seeking-way-to-end-forced-marriages.htm |archive-date=4 October 2013 |accessdate=1 December 2012}}{{cite report |last=Khanum |first=Nazia |date=March 2008 |title=Forced marriage, family cohesion and community engagement: National learning through a case study in Luton |url=https://www.reducingtherisk.org.uk/cms/sites/reducingtherisk/files/folders/resources/hbv_forced_marriage/FM_family_cohesion_community_engagement.pdf |publisher=Equality in Diversity |page=43}} The results suggest that several thousand young women are the victims of forced marriages in Britain each year.{{cite news |title=Fears over forced marriage levels |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/7288952.stm |work=BBC News |date=11 March 2008 |accessdate=1 December 2012}}{{cite news |last=Taylor |first=Matthew |date=11 March 2008 |title=Victims of forced marriages could total 4,000, says study |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/11/gender.communities |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |accessdate=1 December 2012}}{{cite book |last=Macey |first=M. |date=2010 |title=Ethnic, Racial and Religious Inequalities: The Perils of Subjectivity |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pJeGDAAAQBAJ&pg=PA102 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK |pages=102 |isbn=978-0-230-29487-5}} ==Awards and recognition== In 2006, Khanum was appointed an [[Officer of the Order of the British Empire]] (OBE) in the [[2006 New Year Honours]] for her services to equal opportunities and community relations.{{cite news |title=Bangladeshi awarded OBE |url=http://archive.thedailystar.net/2006/01/06/d60106061875.htm |location=Bangladesh |newspaper=[[The Daily Star (Bangladesh)|The Daily Star]] |date=6 January 2006 |accessdate=1 January 2014}} She holds an [[honorary doctorate]] from [[University of Bedfordshire]].{{cite news|last=|first=|url=http://www.beds.ac.uk/news/2008/jun/080609-khanum|title=Seminar examines forced marriages|work=|location=Bedfordshire|publisher=The University of Bedfordshire|date=9 June 2008|archive-url=https://archive.is/20140101210920/http://www.beds.ac.uk/news/2008/jun/080609-khanum|archive-date=1 January 2014|accessdate=1 January 2014|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}} ==Personal life== Khanum is married to David Cheesman, a professor of society and development at [[Sheffield Hallam University]]. Their son, Tareen, has an MSc in economics from the [[London School of Economics|London School of Economics and Political Science]], University of London. In November 2002, Khanum and her husband performed their first [[Hajj]] (the largest Islamic pilgrimage to [[Mecca]], [[Saudi Arabia]]). ==See also== * [[British Bangladeshi]] * [[List of British Bangladeshis]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.ucc.ie/law/blogs/ccjhr/2008/03/report-on-forced-marriage-in-uk.html Report on Forced Marriage in the UK]. ''Centre for Criminal Justice & Human Rights''. 14 March 2008 {{DEFAULTSORT:Khanum, Nazia}} [[Category:1943 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Date of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Bangladeshi Muslims]] [[Category:British Muslims]] [[Category:Bangladeshi emigrants to England]] [[Category:British people of Bangladeshi descent]] [[Category:Naturalised citizens of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:British activists]] [[Category:British management consultants]] [[Category:British special advisers]] [[Category:British women academics]] [[Category:British Asian writers]] [[Category:Muslim writers]] [[Category:21st-century British writers]] [[Category:21st-century women writers]] [[Category:Researchers]] [[Category:Deputy Lieutenants of Bedfordshire]] [[Category:School governors]] [[Category:People from Barisal]] [[Category:People from Dhaka]] [[Category:People from Luton]] [[Category:University of Dhaka alumni]] [[Category:Alumni of SOAS, University of London]] [[Category:Officers of the Order of the British Empire]]

revision.text:
{{about|the CAD program, PLOP|the computer language conference group, PLoP|Pattern Languages of Programs}}
'''PLate OPtimizer''', or '''PLOP''' is a [[CAD program]] used by [[Amateur telescope making|amateur telescope makers]] to design [[primary mirror]] [[Mirror support cell|support cells]] for [[reflecting telescope]]s. It was developed by [[telescope]] maker David Lewis, first described in 1999,<ref>{{Cite journal| title = Cures for Unsupportive Mirror Cells| last = Lewis| first = David| journal = Sky & Telescope| volume = | issue = June| pages = 132–135| date = 1999 }}</ref> and used to simplify calculations needed in the design of mirror support cells.<ref>{{cite web| last = Holm| first = Mark| title = Mirror Cells for Amateur Telescope Makers| work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.atmsite.org/contrib/Holm/Plop_optimized_cells/index.html| doi = | accessdate = May 3, 2009 }} </ref> It was based on Toshimi Taki's 1993 program PLATE,<ref>http://www.asahi-net.or.jp/~zs3t-tk/cell/cell.htm Taki's brief intro to cell design</ref> with a simplified user interface, thus giving it wide acceptance among makers of large [[Dobsonian]] style amateur telescopes, with good support of mirrors as thin as two inches for a diameter of thirty inches.<ref>{{cite web| last = Anderson-Lee | first = Jeff| title = Best of 18 and Over - A collection of plop cell designs | work = | publisher = | date = | url = http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~jonah/18plus/| format =| doi = | accessdate = May 3, 2009}}</ref>
==Comparisons and limitations== A basic mirror cell may be built using minimal calculation and simple materials such as wood and outdoor carpet, with a good example being [[John Dobson (astronomer)|Dobson's]] original telescopes. However, as amateurs sought to build larger and thinner mirrors, they found such designs inadequate.
Many amateur telescope makers use cells which are designed via [[equal area rule]] calculation, using programs such as David Chandler's [[public domain]] program, ''Cell''.<ref>{{Cite web| last = Chandler| first = David| title = Floatation Mirror Cell Design| url = http://www.davidchandler.com/cell.htm| accessdate = 2009-06-21| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090817122733/http://www.davidchandler.com/cell.htm| archivedate = 2009-08-17| df = }}</ref> However, such calculation does not account for mechanical stresses introduced in one part of a telescope mirror by another part, whereas [[finite element analysis]] can be used to reduce such [[Yield (engineering)|stress]]. Although general finite element analysis programs such as [[Nastran]] will work for mirror cells, an advantage of PLOP is that it can be set to ignore [[Deformation (engineering)|deformation]] that merely results in refocus of a mirror's [[parabola]].<ref>[http://www.atmsite.org/contrib/Holm/Plop_optimized_cells/cellfaq.html#old Atmsite PLOP FAQ]</ref> PLOP can be used to calculate floating support points for a mirror's [[Optical axis|axial]] (rear) support; however, additional tools are needed to calculate potential error from a mirror's lateral (edge) support.<ref>http://www.cruxis.com/scope/mirroredgecalculator.htm ''Cruxis'' site mirror edge support calculator tool</ref>
Mirror cell calculations, whether using PLOP or another program, do not overcome errors introduced by gluing the mirror to its cell, excessive tightening of edge supports, nor impingement of the cell structure onto the mirror as result of differential cooling shrinkage. The significantly more complex calculations arising from the support needs of large [[honeycomb mirror]]s and those using [[active optics]] systems are outside the design parameters of such programs.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://medusa.as.arizona.edu/lbto/tech/ua9502.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100703082028/http://medusa.as.arizona.edu/lbto/tech/ua9502.htm |archivedate=2010-07-03 |df= }} Mirror Support System for Large Honeycomb Mirrors</ref>
==See also== * [[Amateur astronomy]] * [[Amateur telescope making]] * [[List of telescope parts and construction]] * [[MATLAB]] * [[Nastran]] * [[Optical aberration]] * [[Optical telescope]] * [[Whiffletree]]
==Notes== {{reflist|2}}
==External resources== * [http://www.cs.berkeley.edu/~jonah/18plus/p18.html A Study of 18-point Mirror Cell Optimization Using Varying Forces] Jeff Anderson-Lee, January 2003 * [http://www.davidlewistoronto.com/plop/ David Lewis, Automated Mirror Cell Optimization] * [http://www.cruxis.com/scope/scope1100_mirrorcell.htm Mechanical design of the 110 cm cruxis telescope] * [http://stellafane.org/misc/links.html Stellafane links page]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Plate Optimizer}} [[Category:Computer-aided design software]] [[Category:Finite element software]] [[Category:Telescopes]] [[Category:Amateur astronomy|Telescope making]]

revision.text:
[[File:Pendule astronomique de Passemant (19).JPG|thumb|Clockface]] The '''Passemant astronomical clock''' is an [[astronomical clock]] designed by Claude-Simeon Passemant in the eighteenth century.<ref name=AllV /> It is displayed in the ''Salon de la pendule'' in the [[petit appartement du roi]] on the first floor of [[Palace of Versailles|Versailles]], France. The clock set the official time in [[France]] for the first time in the kingdom's history.<ref name="S&V">{{cite journal|language=fr|last=Kergoat|first=Morgane|year=2010|title=Les plus beaux instruments des sciences à l'honneur|journal=Les Cahiers de Science & Vie|issue=hors-série ''Les Sciences au château de Versailles''|page=140|url=http://www.science-et-vie.com/Sommaire.asp?Type=CSV&num=119|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928230817/http://www.science-et-vie.com/Sommaire.asp?Type=CSV&num=119|archivedate=2011-09-28|df=}}</ref>
[[File:Pendule astronomique de Passemant (25).JPG|thumb|Passemant astronomical clock]]
==Description== The clock is an exceptional [[rococo]] work over {{convert|2|m}} in height, crowned with a moving celestial sphere. It shows the date, time, real time average phases of the moon and [[Heliocentrism|Copernican]] planetary motion. The large astronomical dials mark the rising and setting of the sun and moon every day. Earth is represented by a bronze globe on which all countries are engraved with the main cities. This globe is placed among the rocks and waterfalls, which serve as a universal horizon.
The mechanism is designed to be able to display the date until the end of the year 9999.<ref name ="S&V"/>
==Creators== The clock mechanism was designed by engineer Claude-Siméon Passemant (1702–1769) and executed by the clockmaker Louis Dauthiau (1730–1809).<ref name= Babelon>''Versailles: absolutism and harmony'' by Jean Pierre Babelon, Claire Constans 1998 {{ISBN|2-7028-1125-6}} page 174</ref> The rococo-style gilt-bronze box protecting the mechanism was made in 1753 by sculptor [[Jean-Jacques Caffieri]] (1735–1792) and bronze-founder [[Philippe Caffieri (1714–1774)|Philippe Caffieri]].
==History== After being reviewed and approved by the [[French Academy of Sciences]] in August 1749, the clock was presented to [[Louis XV of France|Louis XV]] in [[Château de Choisy|Choisy]] by the [[Michel Ferdinand d'Albert d'Ailly|duc de Chaulnes]] on 7 September 1750.<ref name=AllV >[https://books.google.com/books?id=qosM6YrWB_cC&pg=PA62&dq=Passemant+astronomical+clock&hl=en&ei=kZwiTrjGMcSe-QbK86ywAw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CE4Q6AEwCQ#v=onepage&q=Passemant%20astronomical%20clock&f=false ''All Versailles'' by J. G. D' Hoste 1988 ASIN B0007BXHLQ page 62]</ref> The King acquired it the same year. In January 1754, the clock took its place among the astronomical clocks of Versailles. The fact that it was placed in the ''Salon de la pendule'' demonstrates the interest that Louis XV had in the mechanical arts through clockmaking. Indeed, the room was so named because the dials of clocks were set into the wall panelling.
==See also== *[[Gnomon of Saint-Sulpice]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{en icon}} [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=L9DSiAILKsI Astronomical clock] (sciences.chateauversailles.fr)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Passemant Astronomical Clock}} [[Category:Astronomical clocks]] [[Category:Historical scientific instruments]] [[Category:History of astrology]] [[Category:Clocks in France]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:Polar T<sub>3</sub> syndrome}}
'''Polar Triiodothyronine, also known as''' '''Polar T<sub>3</sub> syndrome,''' is a condition found in [[polar explorer]]s, caused by a decrease in levels of the [[thyroid hormone]] [[Triiodothyronine|T<sub>3</sub>]].<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Reed HL, Silverman ED, Shakir KM, Dons R, Burman KD, O'Brian JT | title = Changes in serum triiodothyronine (T3) kinetics after prolonged Antarctic residence: the polar T3 syndrome | journal = The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism | volume = 70 | issue = 4 | pages = 965–74 | date = April 1990 | pmid = 2318952 | pmc = | doi = 10.1210/jcem-70-4-965 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Palinkas LA, Suedfeld P | title = Psychological effects of polar expeditions | journal = Lancet | volume = 371 | issue = 9607 | pages = 153–63 | date = January 2008 | pmid = 17655924 | pmc = | doi = 10.1016/S0140-6736(07)61056-3 }}</ref> Its effects include [[forgetfulness]], [[cognitive impairment]] and [[mood disturbance]]s. It can exhibit itself in a [[fugue state]] known as the ''Antarctic stare''.<ref name=palinkas1997>{{cite web|title=Association between the Polar T3 Syndrome and the Winter-Over Syndrome in Antarctica|url=https://www.nsf.gov/pubs/1999/nsf98106/98106htm/nsf98106h2.html|vauthors=Palinkas LA, Reed HL, Do NV |publisher=Antarctic Journal of the United States Review 1997|year=1997|access-date=2011-11-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Treating the Antarctic blues|url=http://www.spaceref.com/news/viewpr.html?pid=15478|author=Emily Stone|date=November 9, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Polar T3 Disorder|url=http://www.nhm.ac.uk/nature-online/earth/antarctica/blog-archive/?p=185|publisher=Natural History Museum|date=17 April 2008}}</ref>It is regarded as one of the contributory causes of [[winter-over syndrome]].<ref name="palinkas1997" />
== Causes == The exact cause of Polar T3 syndrome is unknown, but there are certain characteristics of this syndrome that are shared with patients that have [http://www.patientcareonline.com/thyroid-disorders/subclinical-thyroid-disease-when-treat-and-how subclinical hypothyroidism].<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsf.gov/pubs/1999/nsf98106/98106htm/nsf98106h2.html|title=Medicine|website=www.nsf.gov|access-date=2018-09-10}}</ref> One common [[Biomarker|bio-marker]] that is known is the [http://www.yourhormones.info/hormones/thyroid-stimulating-hormone/ thyroid-stimulating hormone] (TSH), which is a hormone that leads to a cascade of other hormones being released that affect the pituitary gland.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Yamashita|first=Koh|last2=Suganuma|first2=Kazuki|last3=Funase|first3=Yoshiko|last4=Yamauchi|first4=Keishi|last5=Aizawa|first5=Toru|date=2012-12|title=Elevation of thyrotropin upon accidental hypothermia in an elderly man|journal=Thyroid: Official Journal of the American Thyroid Association|volume=22|issue=12|pages=1291–1293|doi=10.1089/thy.2012.0084|issn=1557-9077|pmid=23083443}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.yourhormones.info/hormones/thyrotropin-releasing-hormone/|title=Thyrotropin-releasing hormone {{!}} You and Your Hormones from the Society for Endocrinology|website=www.yourhormones.info|language=en|access-date=2018-09-20}}</ref> This hormone in particular is found in large quantities in people with Polar T3 syndrome. Additionally, other hormonal changes include a significant decrease in [[triiodothyronine]] (T3) and [[thyroxine]] (T4).<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> All of these biochemical alterations are thought to be due to the extreme cold and dark winter months.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|vauthors=Palinkas LA, Suedfeld P|date=January 2008|title=Psychological effects of polar expeditions|journal=Lancet|volume=371|issue=9607|pages=153–63|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(07)61056-3|pmc=|pmid=17655924}}</ref> Other attributing factors are changes in the [[circadian rhythm]] patterns and lack of social interaction.<ref name=":0" />
== Symptoms == People diagnosed with Polar T3 syndrome are known to have a variety of symptoms including [https://www.hopkinsguides.com/hopkins/view/Johns_Hopkins_Psychiatry_Guide/787026/all/Sleep_Disruption sleep disruptions], [[mental impairment]], and [[Mood swing|mood changes]]. [https://www.webmd.com/sleep-disorders/default.htm Sleep disruptions] include inability to fall asleep or stay asleep and are more prominent in the winter months, according to a study done by [https://pressroom.usc.edu/lawrence-a-palinkas/ Palinkas].<ref name=":0" /> Most of these sleep disruptions are characterized by a decrease in [http://www.centerforsoundsleep.com/sleep-disorders/stages-of-sleep/ short wave sleep] and [[Rapid eye movement sleep|rapid eye movement]] (REM).<ref name=":0" /> The Palinkas survey concluded that on average 64% of people living in the [https://www.lonelyplanet.com/antarctica-1007062 Antarctic polar region] are affected by some sort of [https://www.healthline.com/health/sleep/disorders sleep disruption].<ref name=":0" /> In addition to problems with sleep, 51.5% of people suffer from [[cognitive impairment]].<ref name=":0" /> This type of deficiency includes a decline in proficient memorization and the inability to concentrate.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> Other areas of [[mental impairment]] are [[mood changes]] ([[Negative affectivity|negative affect]]).<ref name=":0" /> These include depression, anxiety, and irritability throughout the winter months.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== Diagnosis and Treatment == When determining if a person has Polar T3 syndrome multiple aspects are taken into consideration. [http://www.yourarticlelibrary.com/experiments/importance-of-biochemical-tests-of-bacteria/26624 Biochemical tests] can be carried out which test for differences in [https://www.everydayhealth.com/hs/healthy-living-with-hypothyroidism/understanding-test-results/ serum thyroid] and [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/2679028 plasma lipid levels].<ref name=":1" /> The main purpose of these tests are to gain insight on the [[thyroid]] function.<ref name=":1" /> Other assessments include analysis of changes in mood and memory function.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> If a person is diagnosed with Polar T3 syndrome using the assessments mentioned above, then [[Hormone therapy|hormonal therapy]] is commonly prescribed including [https://www.endocrineweb.com/conditions/hypothyroidism/synthetic-t4-supplements-hypothyroidism thyroxine supplements.]<ref name=":1" />
== References == <references />
[[Category:Polar exploration]] [[Category:Thyroid disease]] [[Category:Syndromes]]
{{antarctica-stub}} {{endocrine-disease-stub}}

{{Unreferenced stub|auto=yes|date=December 2009}} A '''proper frame''', or '''comoving frame''', is a [[frame of reference]] that is attached to an object. The object in this frame is stationary within the frame, which is useful for many types of calculations.
For example, a freely falling [[elevator]] is a proper frame for a [[Free fall|free-falling]] object in the elevator, while the surface of the Earth is not.
Proper frames can be [[Inertial_reference_frame|inertial]] and [[Non-inertial_reference_frame|non-inertial]], as in the example above.
The use of a proper frame is essential for the investigation of physical laws within the framework of [[general relativity]].
== See also == * [[Proper reference frame (flat spacetime)]] * [[Comoving distance]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Proper Frame}} [[Category:Frames of reference]]
{{Relativity-stub}}

revision.text:
{{for|the Revelation Space character|Characters in Revelation Space#Remontoire}}
In mechanical [[horology]], a '''remontoire''' (from the French ''remonter'', meaning 'to wind') is a small secondary source of power, a weight or [[spring (device)|spring]], which runs the timekeeping mechanism and is itself periodically rewound by the timepiece's main power source, such as a [[mainspring]]. It was used in precision [[clock]]s and [[watch]]es to place the source of power closer to the [[escapement]], thereby increasing the accuracy by evening out variations in drive force caused by unevenness of the [[friction]] in the geartrain. In spring-driven precision clocks, a gravity remontoire is often used to replace the uneven force delivered by the mainspring running down by the more constant force of gravity acting on a weight. In [[turret clock]]s, it serves to separate the large forces needed to drive the hands from the modest forces needed to drive the [[escapement]] which keeps the [[pendulum]] swinging. A remontoire should not be confused with a ''[[maintaining power]] spring'', which is used only to keep the timepiece going while it is being wound.
==How it works== Remontoires are used because the timekeeping mechanism in clocks and watches, the [[pendulum]] or [[balance wheel]], is never [[isochronous]]; its rate is affected by changes in the drive force applied to it. In spring-driven timepieces, the drive force declines as the [[mainspring]] runs down. In weight-driven clocks the drive force, provided by a weight suspended by a cord, is more constant, but imperfections in the gear train and variations in lubrication also cause small variations. In [[turret clock]]s, the large hands, which are attached to the clock's wheel train, are exposed to the weather on the outside of the tower, so winds and accumulations of ice and snow apply disturbing forces to the hands, which are passed on to the wheel train.
With a remontoire, the only force applied to the clock's [[escapement]] is that of the remontoire's spring or weight, so that it is isolated from any variations in the main power source or wheel train, which is just used to rewind the remontoire. Remontoires are designed to rewind frequently, at intervals between fifteen seconds and an hour. The rewinding process is triggered automatically when the remontoire's weight or spring reaches the end of its power. This frequent rewinding is another source of accuracy, because it averages out any variations in the clock's rate due to changes in the force of the remontoire itself. If the rate of the clock varies as the remontoire spring runs down, this variation will be repeated again and again, each time the remontoire goes through its cycle, so it will have no effect on the long term rate of the clock.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | title = Clocks | encyclopedia = Encyclopædia Britannica, 11th Ed. | volume = 6 | pages = | publisher = The Encyclopædia Britannica Co., Cambridge | year = 1910 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=6jcEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA544&dq=remontoire | id = | accessdate = 2008-06-08}} p.543-544</ref>
==History== The gravity remontoire was invented by Swiss clockmaker [[Jost Burgi]] around 1595. Usually the "Kalenderuhr" (three month running, springdriven, calendar-desk-clock) Burgi made for [[William IV, Landgrave of Hesse-Kassel]] (or Hesse-Cassel) (now Inventory No. U 47 at the Naturwissenschaftlich-Technische Sammlung in Kassel) is considered the oldest surviving clock with a remontoire, even if it does not provide power to the escapement during the few seconds of the daily cycle where the remontoire weight gets wound up by the spring.<ref>Karsten Gaulke: Der Ptolemãus von Kassel; Kassel: 2007; {{ISBN|978-3-931787-43-1}}, Page 143</ref> Today remontoire mechanisms are all designed to deliver power to the escapement during the remontoire reset cycle.
The spring remontoire was invented by English clockmaker [[John Harrison]] during development of his H2 [[marine chronometer]] in 1739. Harrison's working drawing of the device is preserved in the Library of the Worshipful Company of Clockmakers in London, England.<ref>"Mechanical Notes and Drawing Compiled by John Harrison and his son William c.1726-1772", p.13</ref>
Many French and Swiss [[pocketwatch]]es after 1860 were stamped on the back with the word ''Remontoire''. This merely meant that they didn't have to be wound with a key (i.e. they were wound by the then-novel winding crown inside the pendant). Etymologically the term is correct, the mainspring is "rewound" by some other force than a key, but these watches usually do not contain a remontoire as the word is used today.<ref>{{cite web |last = Fried |first = Henry B. |authorlink = |coauthors = |title = What is a remontoire? |work = Modern Masterpieces of Horology |publisher = Heritage, Jeweler's Circular Keystone, Cahner's Business Information |date = July 1995 |url = http://jck.polygon.net/archives/1995/07/0795horo.html |doi = |accessdate = 2008-06-23 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060628053646/http://jck.polygon.net/archives/1995/07/0795horo.html |archivedate = 2006-06-28 |df = }}</ref>
==Types== Remontoires are distinguished by their power source: *A ''gravity remontoire'' is one that uses a weight for power. It is used in precision [[pendulum clock]]s. *A ''spring remontoire'' uses a spring. It is the only type which can be used in watches, since the force of a weight would be disturbed by motions of the wearer's wrist *An ''electric remontoire'' can be either a gravity or spring type. In it, the weight or spring is rewound electrically, with a motor or [[solenoid]]. It is used in clocks with traditional mechanical movements which are run on electricity. They can also be classified by where in the wheel train the remontoire is located: *An ''escapement remontoire'' applies its force directly to the escape wheel of the escapement. Spring remontoires were usually of this type. *A ''train remontoire'' applies its force to one of the wheels upstream from the escapement, usually to the wheel that drives the escape wheel.
==Electric remontoires in automobile clocks== Before the common use of electronic clocks in automobiles, automobile clocks had mechanical movements, powered by an electric remontoire. A low power drive spring would be wound every few minutes by a plunger in a [[solenoid]], powered by the vehicle's service battery and activated by a switch when the spring tension got too low. Such clocks were, however, notoriously inaccurate, typically being made as cheaply as possible.
== Footnotes == {{reflist}}
== External links == * http://www.my-time-machines.net/wagner_detail.htm <!-- * http://www.antiquorum.com/html/vox/vox2002/remontoire/remontoire.htm "coming soon" -->
[[Category:Horology]]

revision.text:
'''SIGCSE''' is the [[Association for Computing Machinery]]'s [[Special Interest Group]] on Computer Science Education, which provides a forum for educators to discuss issues related to the development, implementation, and/or evaluation of computing programs, curricula, and courses, as well as syllabi, laboratories, and other elements of teaching and pedagogy. It is also the name of one of the three annual events organized by SIGCSE. This event, the ACM [[SIGCSE Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education]], is held annually in February or March in the USA. SIGCSE also sponsors an annual conference in or around Europe, named ITiCSE (Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education), usually in late June, and an annual research workshop named ICER (International Computing Education Research), at varied locations, usually in August.
The main focus of SIGCSE is higher education, and discussions include improving computer science education at high school level and below. The membership level has held steady at around 3300 members for several years. The current chair of SIGCSE is [[Amber Settle]] for July 1, 2016 to June 30, 2019.
==Conferences==
SIGCSE has three annual conferences.
* The Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education conference is held in the United States with an average annual attendance of approximately 1300. The next conference will be held February 27 through March 2, 2019 in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sigcse2019.sigcse.org/|title=SIGCSE 2019|website=sigcse2019.sigcse.org|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> * The annual conference on Innovation and Technology in Computer Science Education (ITiCSE). The next one will be held Monday 2 July through Wednesday 4 July 2018 in [[Larnaca, Cyprus]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://iticse.acm.org/|title=ITiCSE 2018|website=iticse.acm.org|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref> This conference is attended by about 200-300 and is mainly held in Europe, but has also been held in countries outside of Europe ([[Turkey]] - 2010), ([[Israel]] - 2012), and ([[Peru]] - 2016). * The International Computing Education Research (ICER) Conference. This conference has about 70 attendees and is held in the United States every other year. On the alternate years it rotates between [[Europe]] and [[Australasia]]. The next conference will be held August 13 through August 15, 2018 in [[Espoo, Finland]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://icer.acm.org/|title=ICER Conference {{!}} International Computing Education Research|website=icer.acm.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-03-11}}</ref>
==Newsletter/Bulletin== The SIGCSE Bulletin is a quarterly newsletter that was first published in 1969. It evolved from an informal gathering of news and ideas to a venue for columns, editor-reviewed articles, research announcements, editorials, symposium proceedings, etc.
In 2010, with the inception of ACM Inroads magazine, the Bulletin was transformed into an electronic newsletter sent to all SIGCSE members providing communications about SIGCSE: announcing activities, publicizing events, and highlighting topics of interest. In other words, it has returned to its roots.
==Awards== SIGCSE has two main awards that are given out annually.
===Outstanding Contribution Award===
The SIGCSE Award for Outstanding Contribution to Computer Science Education is given annually since 1981. Winners are the following:
* [[Tim Bell (computer scientist)|Tim Bell]], 2018 * [[Gail Chapman]], 2017 * [[Janice E. Cuny]], 2016 * [[Mark Allen Weiss]], 2015 * [[Robert Panoff]], 2014 * [[Michael Kolling]], 2013 * [[Harold Abelson]], 2012 * [[Matthias Felleisen]], 2011 * [[Sally Fincher]], 2010 * [[Elliott Koffman]], 2009 * [[Randy Pausch]], 2008 * [[Judith Gal-Ezer]], 2007 * [[John Hughes (computer scientist)|John Hughes]], 2007 * [[Richard Pattis]], 2006 * [[Kim Bruce]], 2005 * [[Mordechai Ben-Ari]], 2004 * [[Eric S. Roberts]], 2003 * [[Elliot Soloway]], 2002 * [[Allen B. Tucker]], 2001 * [[Andries van Dam]], 2000 * [[Peter J. Denning]], 1999 * [[William Wulf]], 1998 * [[Andrew Tanenbaum]], 1997 * [[Nell B. Dale]], 1996 * [[Robert Aiken]], 1995 * [[Norman Gibbs]], 1994 * [[Alan Kay]], 1993 * [[Daniel McCracken]], 1992 * [[David Gries]], 1991 * Curriculum 1968 Committee, 1990 * [[Edsger Dijkstra]], 1989 * [[Grace Murray Hopper]], 1988 * [[Niklaus Wirth]], 1987 * [[Donald Knuth]], 1986 * [[Elliot Organick]], 1985 * [[Karl Karlstrom]], 1984 * [[Alan Perlis]], 1982 * [[William Atchison]], 1981
===Lifetime Service Award=== The SIGCSE Award for Lifetime Service to the Computer Science Education Community is given annually since 1997. Winners are the following:
* [[Mats Daniels]], 2017 * [[Barbara Boucher Owens]], 2016 * [[Frank Young (educator)|Frank Young]], 2015 * [[Andrea Lawrence (professor)|Andrea Lawrence]], 2014 * [[Henry Walker (educator)|Henry Walker]], 2013 * [[Jane Prey]], 2012 * [[Gordon Davies (educator)|Gordon Davies]], 2011 * [[Peter J. Denning]], 2010 * [[Michael Clancy]], 2009 * [[Dennis J. Frailey]], 2008 * [[John Impagliazzo]], 2007 * [[Joyce Currie Little]], 2006 * [[Andrew McGettrick]], 2005 * [[Bruce Klein]], 2004 * [[Harriet Taylor]], 2003 * [[A. Joe Turner]], 2002 * [[Lillian N. (Boots) Cassel]], 2001 * [[James Miller (educator)|James Miller]], 2000 * [[Bob Aiken]], 1999 * [[Della Bonnette]], 1998 * [[Dick Austing]], 1997
==SIGCSE Board== The current SIGCSE Board for July 1, 2016 – June 30, 2019 is:
* [[Amber Settle]], Chair * [[Susan H. Rodger]], Past Chair * [[Judith Sheard]], Vice-Chair * [[Adrienne Decker]], Treasurer * [[Sue Fitzgerald]], Secretary * [[Michelle Craig]], at-large member * [[Briana Morrison]], at-large member * [[Mark Allen Weiss]], at-large member
SIGCSE Chairs over the years:
* [[Susan H. Rodger]], 2013–16 * [[Renee McCauley]], 2010-2013 * [[Barbara Boucher Owens]], 2007–10 * [[Henry Walker (educator)|Henry Walker]], 2001-2007 * [[Bruce Klein]], 1997-01 * [[Lillian N. (Boots) Cassel]], 1993–97 * [[Nell B. Dale]], 1991–93
==External links== * [http://www.sigcse.org/ SIGCSE]

[[File:Rheology of time independent fluids.svg|thumb|right|Classification of fluids with shear stress as a function of shear rate: Pseudoplastic, Bingham and Bingham pseudoplastic all show reduction in apparent viscosity with increasing shear rate.]] In [[rheology]], '''shear thinning''' is the [[non-Newtonian fluid|non-Newtonian]] behavior of fluids whose [[viscosity]] decreases under [[shear strain]]. It is sometimes considered synonymous for pseudoplastic behaviour,<ref>{{cite book|last1=Mezger|first1=Thomas G.|title=The rheology handbook : for users of rotational and oscillatory rheometers|date=2006|publisher=Vincentz Network|location=Hannover|isbn=9783878701743|page=34|edition=2., rev.}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Heldman|first1=R. Paul Singh, Dennis R.|title=Introduction to food engineering|date=2013|publisher=Elsevier|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9780124016750|page=160|edition=5th}}</ref> and is usually defined as excluding [[time-dependent viscosity|time-dependent]] effects, such as [[thixotropy]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Bair|first1=Scott|title=High-pressure rheology for quantitative elastohydrodynamics|date=2007|publisher=Elsevier|location=Amsterdam|isbn=9780080475301|page=136|edition=1st|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=5rAHrLxdhRwC&pg=PA136|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref> Shear-thinning behaviour is generally not seen in pure liquids with low [[molecular mass]], or ideal solutions of small molecules like [[sucrose]] or [[sodium chloride]], but is often seen in [[polymer]] solutions and molten polymers, and complex fluids and suspensions like [[ketchup]], [[whipped cream]], [[blood]],<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tazraei|first1=P.|last2=Riasi|first2=A.|last3=Takabi|first3=B.|title=The influence of the non-Newtonian properties of blood on blood-hammer through the posterior cerebral artery|journal=Mathematical Biosciences|date=2015|volume=264|pages=119–127|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0025556415000802|doi=10.1016/j.mbs.2015.03.013}}</ref> [[paint]], and [[nail polish]].
==Relationship with thixotropy== Some authors consider shear-thinning to be a special case of thixotropic behaviour, because the recovery of the microstructure of the liquid to its initial state will always require a non-zero time. When the recovery of viscosity after disturbance is very rapid however, the observed behaviour is classic shear-thinning or pseudoplasticity, because as soon as the shear is removed, the viscosity returns to normal. When it takes a measurable time for the viscosity to recover, thixotropic behaviour is observed.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Barnes|first=Howard A.|title=Thixotropy a review|journal=J. Non-Newtonian Fluid Mech., 70|year=1997|page=3|url=http://www.dfi.uchile.cl/~rsoto/docencia/FluidosNoNewton2008/trixotropia.pdf|accessdate=2011-11-30|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160430015102/http://www.dfi.uchile.cl/~rsoto/docencia/FluidosNoNewton2008/trixotropia.pdf|archivedate=2016-04-30|df=}}</ref> When describing the viscosity of liquids, however, it is therefore useful to distinguish shear-thinning (pseudoplastic) behaviour from thixotropic behaviour, where the viscosity at all shear rates is decreased for some duration after agitation: both of these effects can often be seen separately in the same liquid.<ref>{{cite book|last1=editor|first1=David B. Troy,|title=Remington : The science and practice of pharmacy|date=2005|publisher=Lippincott, Williams & Wilkins|location=Philadelphia, PA|isbn=9780781746731|page=344|edition=21st|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NFGSSSbaWjwC&pg=PA344|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref>
== Everyday examples ==
Modern [[paint]]s are examples of pseudoplastic materials. When modern paints are applied, the shear created by the brush or roller will allow them to thin and wet out the surface evenly. Once applied, the paints regain their higher viscosity, which avoids drips and runs. [[Ketchup]] is a shear-thinning fluid.
== See also ==
* [[Non-Newtonian fluid]] * [[Power-law fluid]] * [[Thixotropy]] * [[Dilatant]] * [[Rheology]] * [[Kaye effect]]
== External links == * [http://www.firstscience.com/site/articles/ketchup.asp The Great Ketchup Mystery] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090901032246/http://science.nasa.gov/headlines/y2008/25apr_cvx2.htm NASA - The Physics of Whipped Cream] [[NASA]] April 25, 2008
References: {{reflist}}
