Adding [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "An exact solution of the Euler equations for periodic surface gravity waves" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|An exact solution of the Euler equations for periodic surface gravity waves}} [[File:Trochoidal wave.svg|thumb|400px|Surface elevation of a trochoidal wave (deep blue) propagating to the right. The trajectories of [[free surface]] particles are close circles (in cyan), and the [[flow velocity]] is shown in red, for the black particles. The [[wave height]] – difference between the crest and trough elevation – is denoted as <math>H</math>, the [[wavelength]] as <math>\lambda</math> and the phase speed as <math>c.</math>]]
In [[fluid dynamics]], a '''trochoidal wave''' or '''Gerstner wave''' is an exact solution of the [[Euler equations (fluid dynamics)|Euler equations]] for [[periodic function|periodic]] [[surface gravity wave]]s. It describes a [[progressive wave]] of permanent form on the surface of an [[incompressible fluid]] of infinite depth. The free surface of this wave solution is an inverted (upside-down) [[trochoid]] – with sharper [[crest (physics)|crest]]s and flat troughs. This wave solution was discovered by [[František Josef Gerstner|Gerstner]] in 1802, and rediscovered independently by [[William John Macquorn Rankine|Rankine]] in 1863.
The flow field associated with the trochoidal wave is not [[irrotational flow|irrotational]]: it has [[vorticity]]. The vorticity is of such a specific strength and vertical distribution that the trajectories of the [[fluid parcel]]s are closed circles. This is in contrast with the usual experimental observation of [[Stokes drift]] associated with the wave motion. Also the [[phase speed]] is independent of the trochoidal wave's [[amplitude]], unlike other nonlinear wave-theories (like those of the [[Stokes wave]] and [[cnoidal wave]]) and observations. For these reasons – as well as for the fact that solutions for finite fluid depth are lacking – trochoidal waves are of limited use for engineering applications.
In [[computer graphics]], the [[rendering (computer graphics)|rendering]] of realistic-looking [[ocean wave]]s can be done by use of so-called '''Gerstner waves'''. This is a multi-component and multi-directional extension of the traditional Gerstner wave, often using [[fast Fourier transform]]s to make (real-time) [[animation]] feasible.<ref name=Tessendorf>{{harvtxt|Tessendorf|2001}}</ref>
==Description of classical trochoidal wave==
Using a [[Lagrangian and Eulerian specification of the flow field|Lagrangian specification of the flow field]], the motion of fluid parcels is – for a [[periodic function|periodic]] wave on the surface of a fluid layer of infinite depth:<ref name=Lamb>{{harvtxt|Lamb|1994|loc=§251}}</ref> :<math> \begin{align} X(a,b,t) &= a + \frac{\mathrm{e}^{kb}}{k} \sin \left( k(a+ct) \right), \\ Y(a,b,t) &= b - \frac{\mathrm{e}^{kb}}{k} \cos \left( k(a+ct) \right), \end{align} </math> where <math>x=X(a,b,t)</math> and <math>y=Y(a,b,t)</math> are the positions of the fluid parcels in the <math>(x,y)</math> plane at time <math>t</math>, with <math>x</math> the horizontal coordinate and <math>y</math> the vertical coordinate (positive upward, in the direction opposing gravity). The Lagrangian coordinates <math>(a,b)</math> label the fluid parcels, with <math>(x,y)=(a,b)</math> the centres of the circular orbits – around which the corresponding fluid parcel moves with constant [[speed]] <math>c\,\exp(kb).</math> Further <math>k=2\pi/\lambda</math> is the [[wavenumber]] (and <math>\lambda</math> the [[wavelength]]), while <math>c</math> is the phase speed with which the wave propagates in the <math>x</math>-direction. The phase speed satisfies the [[dispersion (water waves)|dispersion]] relation:
:<math>c^2=\frac{g}{k},</math>
which is independent of the wave nonlinearity (i.e. does not depend on the wave height <math>H</math>), and this phase speed <math>c</math> the same as for [[Airy wave theory|Airy's linear waves]] in deep water.
The free surface is a line of constant pressure, and is found to correspond with a line <math>b=b_s</math>, where <math>b_s</math> is a (nonpositive) constant. For <math>b_s=0</math> the highest waves occur, with a [[cusp (singularity)|cusp]]-shaped crest. Note that the highest (irrotational) [[Stokes wave]] has a [[wave crest|crest]] angle of 120°, instead of the 0° for the rotational trochoidal wave.<ref>{{citation | first= G.G. | last= Stokes | authorlink=Sir George Stokes, 1st Baronet | year= 1880 | contribution= Supplement to a paper on the theory of oscillatory waves | title= Mathematical and Physical Papers, Volume I | publisher= Cambridge University Press | pages= 314–326 | url=https://archive.org/details/mathphyspapers01stokrich | oclc = 314316422 }}</ref>
The [[wave height]] of the trochoidal wave is <math>H=(2/k)\exp(kb_s).</math> The wave is periodic in the <math>x</math>-direction, with wavelength <math>\lambda;</math> and also periodic in time with [[frequency|period]] <math>T=\lambda/c=\sqrt{2\pi\lambda/g}.</math>
The [[vorticity]] <math>\varpi</math> under the trochoidal wave is:<ref name=Lamb/>
:<math>\varpi(a,b,t) = - \frac{2\,k\,c\,\mathrm{e}^{2kb}}{1-\mathrm{e}^{2kb}},</math>
varying with Lagrangian elevation <math>b</math> and diminishing rapidly with depth below the free surface.
==In computer graphics==
[[File:Gerstner waves 10deg rendering.ogv|thumb|Animation (5 MB) of [[swell (ocean)|swell waves]] using multi-directional and multi-component Gerstner waves for the simulation of the ocean surface and [[POV-Ray]] for the [[3D rendering]]. (The animation is periodic in time; it can be set to loop after right-clicking on it while it is playing).]]
A multi-component and multi-directional extension of the [[Lagrangian and Eulerian specification of the flow field|Lagrangian description]] of the free-surface motion – as used in Gerstner's trochoidal wave – is used in [[computer graphics]] for the simulation of ocean waves.<ref name=Tessendorf/> For the classical Gerstner wave the fluid motion exactly satisfies the nonlinear, [[incompressible]] and [[inviscid]] flow equations below the free surface. However, the extended Gerstner waves do in general not satisfy these flow equations exactly (although they satisfy them approximately, i.e. for the linearised Lagrangian description by [[potential flow]]). This description of the ocean can be programmed very efficiently by use of the [[fast Fourier transform]] (FFT). Moreover, the resulting ocean waves from this process look realistic, as a result of the nonlinear deformation of the free surface (due to the Lagrangian specification of the motion): sharper [[crest (physics)|crest]]s and flatter [[trough (physics)|trough]]s.
The mathematical description of the free-surface in these Gerstner waves can be as follows:<ref name=Tessendorf/> the horizontal coordinates are denoted as <math>x</math> and <math>z</math>, and the vertical coordinate is <math>y</math>. The [[average|mean]] level of the free surface is at <math>y=0</math> and the positive <math>y</math>-direction is upward, opposing the [[Earth's gravity]] of strength <math>g.</math> The free surface is described [[parametric equation|parametrically]] as a function of the parameters <math>\alpha</math> and <math>\beta,</math> as well as of time <math>t.</math> The parameters are connected to the mean-surface points <math>(x,y,z)=(\alpha,0,\beta)</math> around which the [[fluid parcel]]s at the wavy surface orbit. The free surface is specified through <math>x=\xi(\alpha,\beta,t),</math> <math>y=\zeta(\alpha,\beta,t)</math> and <math>z=\eta(\alpha,\beta,t)</math> with:
:<math> \begin{align} \xi &= \alpha - \sum_{m=1}^M \frac{k_{x,m}}{k_m}\, \frac{a_m}{\tanh\left( k_m\, h \right)}\, \sin\left( \theta_m \right), \\ \eta &= \beta - \sum_{m=1}^M \frac{k_{z,m}}{k_m}\, \frac{a_m}{\tanh\left( k_m\, h \right)}\, \sin\left( \theta_m \right), \\ \zeta &= \sum_{m=1}^M a_m\, \cos\left( \theta_m \right) \quad\text{and} \\ \theta_m &= k_{x,m}\, \alpha + k_{z,m}\, \beta - \omega_m\, t - \phi_m, \end{align} </math>
where <math>\tanh</math> is the [[hyperbolic tangent]] function, <math>M</math> is the number of wave components considered, <math>a_m</math> is the [[amplitude]] of component <math>{m=1\dots M}</math> and <math>\phi_m</math> its phase. Further <math>{k_m=\scriptstyle\sqrt{(k_{x,m}^2+k_{z,m}^2)}}</math> is its [[wavenumber]] and <math>\omega_m</math> its [[angular frequency]]. The latter two, <math>k_m</math> and <math>\omega_m,</math> can not be chosen independently but are related through the [[dispersion (water waves)|dispersion relation]]:
:<math>\omega_m^2 = g\, k_m\, \tanh \left( k_m\, h \right),</math>
with <math>h</math> the mean water depth. In deep water (<math>h\to\infty</math>) the hyperbolic tangent goes to one: <math>{\tanh(k_m\,h)\to 1.}</math> The components <math>k_{x,m}</math> and <math>k_{z,m}</math> of the horizontal wavenumber [[vector (mathematics and physics)|vector]] <math>\boldsymbol{k}_m</math> determine the wave propagation direction of component <math>m.</math>
The choice of the various parameters <math>a_m, k_{x,m}, k_{z,m}</math> and <math>\phi_m</math> for <math>{m=1,\dots,{M},}</math> and a certain mean depth <math>h</math> determines the form of the ocean surface. A clever choice is needed in order to exploit the possibility of fast computation by means of the FFT. See e.g. {{harvtxt|Tessendorf|2001}} for a description how to do this. Most often, the wavenumbers are chosen on a regular grid in <math>(k_x,k_z)</math>-space. Thereafter, the amplitudes <math>a_m</math> and phases <math>\phi_m</math> are chosen randomly in accord with the [[spectral density|variance-density spectrum]] of a certain desired [[sea state]]. Finally, by FFT, the ocean surface can be constructed in such a way that it is [[periodic function|periodic]] both in space and time, enabling [[tessellation (computer graphics)|tiling]] – creating periodicity in time by slightly shifting the frequencies <math>\omega_m</math> such that <math>\omega_m=m\,\Delta\omega</math> for <math>{m=1,\dots,{M}.}</math>
In rendering, also the [[normal (geometry)|normal vector]] <math>\boldsymbol{n}</math> to the surface is often needed. These can be computed using the [[cross product]] (<math>\times</math>) as:
:<math> \boldsymbol{n} = \frac{\partial\boldsymbol{s}}{\partial\alpha} \times \frac{\partial\boldsymbol{s}}{\partial\beta} \quad \text{with} \quad \boldsymbol{s}(\alpha,\beta,t) = \begin{pmatrix} \xi(\alpha,\beta,t) \\ \zeta(\alpha,\beta,t) \\ \eta(\alpha,\beta,t) \end{pmatrix}. </math>
The [[unit vector|unit]] normal vector then is <math>\boldsymbol{e}_n=\boldsymbol{n}/\|\boldsymbol{n}\|,</math> with <math>\|\boldsymbol{n}\|</math> the [[norm (mathematics)|norm]] of <math>\boldsymbol{n}.</math>

==References==

Reprinted in: ''Annalen der Physik'' '''32'''(8), pp. 412–445, 1809. *{{citation | first=A.D.D. | last=Craik | year=2004 | title=The origins of water wave theory | journal=Annual Review of Fluid Mechanics | volume=36 | pages=1–28 | doi=10.1146/annurev.fluid.36.050802.122118 |bibcode = 2004AnRFM..36....1C }} *{{citation | first=H. | last=Lamb | authorlink=Horace Lamb | year=1994 | title=Hydrodynamics | publisher=Cambridge University Press | edition=6th | isbn=978-0-521-45868-9 | oclc=30070401 | pages=§251 | nopp=yes }} Originally published in 1879, the 6th extended edition appeared first in 1932. *{{citation | first=W.J.M. | last=Rankine | authorlink=William John Macquorn Rankine | year=1863 | title=On the exact form of waves near the surface of deep water | journal=Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London | volume=153 | pages=127–138 | doi=10.1098/rstl.1863.0006 }} *{{citation |contribution=Simulating ocean water |last=Tessendorf |first=J. |title=[[SIGGRAPH]] 2001 |issue=Simulating Nature: Realistic and Interactive Techniques |year=2001 |contribution-url=http://www-evasion.imag.fr/Membres/Fabrice.Neyret/NaturalScenes/fluids/water/waves/fluids-nuages/waves/Jonathan/articlesCG/simulating-ocean-water-01.pdf |chapter-format=PDF |pages=26 pp. |nopp=yes }} {{ref end}}

'''USS ''Hornet'' (CV/CVA/CVS-12)''' is a [[United States Navy]] [[aircraft carrier]] of the [[Essex class aircraft carrier|''Essex'' class]]. Construction started in August 1942. She was originally named {{USS|Kearsarge}} but was renamed in honor of the prior {{USS|Hornet|CV-8}}, which was lost in October 1942, becoming the eighth ship to bear the name.
''Hornet'' was commissioned 29 November 1943, and after three months of training joined the [[United States|U.S.]] forces in the [[Pacific War]]. She played a major part in the Pacific battles of [[World War II]], and also took part in [[Operation Magic Carpet]], returning troops to the U.S. Following World War II, she served in the [[Vietnam War]], and also played a part in the [[Apollo program]], recovering the [[Apollo 11]] and [[Apollo 12]] astronauts as they returned from the Moon.
''Hornet'' was finally decommissioned in 1970. She was eventually designated as both a [[National Historic Landmark]] and a [[California Historical Landmark]], and in 1998 she opened to the public as the [[USS Hornet Museum|USS ''Hornet'' Museum]] in [[Alameda, California]].
==Construction: 1940 to 1943== The contract to build ''Kearsarge'' had been given to [[Northrop Grumman Newport News|Newport News Shipbuilding]] on 9 September 1940, and her keel was laid down on 3 August 1942. The seventh {{USS|Hornet|CV-8|3}} was sunk in the [[Battle of the Santa Cruz Islands|Battle of Santa Cruz]] on 26 October 1942, and the CV-12 hull was renamed ''Hornet'' (the name ''Kearsarge'' is still stamped into her [[keel plate]]).{{Citation needed|date=May 2008}} Larger and more advanced than her [[Yorktown class aircraft carrier|Yorktown-class]] namesake, she was launched on 30 August 1943 and [[Ship commissioning|commissioned]] on 29 November 1943. Her first commander was [[Captain (naval)|Captain]] (later [[Rear Admiral]]) [[Miles R. Browning]].
==Service history==
===World War II: 1944 to 1947=== The ''Hornet'' conducted shakedown training off [[Bermuda]] before departing Norfolk on 14 February 1944 to join the [[Fast Carrier Task Force]] on 20 March at [[Majuro Atoll]] in the [[Marshall Islands]]. After lending air support to protect the invasion beaches in [[New Guinea]], she conducted massive aerial raids against Japanese bases in the [[Caroline Islands]] and prepared to support the amphibious assault for the occupation of the [[Marianas Islands]].
[[File:USS Hornet (CV-12) underway in early 1945 (NNAM.2000.290.008).jpg|thumb|left|''Hornet'' in early 1945.]]
On 11 June, ''Hornet'' launched raids on [[Tinian]] and [[Saipan]]. The following day she conducted heavy bombing attacks on [[Guam]] and [[Rota (island)|Rota]]. On 15–16 June, she blasted Japanese air fields at [[Iwo Jima]] and [[Chichi Jima]] to prevent air attacks on troops invading Saipan in the Marianas. The afternoon of 18 June, ''Hornet'' formed with the Fast Carrier Task Force to intercept the Japanese First Mobile Fleet, headed through the Philippine Sea for Saipan. The [[Battle of the Philippine Sea]] began on 19 June, when ''Hornet'' launched strikes to destroy as many land-based Japanese planes as possible before the carrier-based Japanese aircraft came in effectively.
The Japanese approached the American carriers in four massive waves, full of young and inexperienced pilots. [[Fighter aircraft]] from ''Hornet'' and other U.S. carriers, whose veteran pilots' skills were honed to perfection, broke up and savaged all the attacks before the Japanese aerial raiders reached the task force. Nearly every Japanese aircraft was shot down in the great air battles of 19 June that became commonly known as "[[Battle of the Philippine Sea|The Marianas Turkey Shoot]]". As the Japanese Mobile Fleet fled in defeat on 20 June, the carriers launched long-range airstrikes that sank the {{Ship|Japanese aircraft carrier|Hiyō}} and so damaged two tankers that they were abandoned and scuttled. [[Vice Admiral]] [[Jisaburō Ozawa]]'s own flag log for 20 June 1944 showed his surviving carrier air power as only 35 operational aircraft out of the 430 planes with which he had commenced the Battle of the Philippine Sea.
''Hornet'', based at [[Eniwetok]] in the Marshalls, raided Japanese installations ranging from Guam to the Bonins, then turned her attention to the Palaus, throughout the [[Philippine Sea]], and to Japanese bases on [[Okinawa]] and [[Taiwan|Formosa]]. Her aircraft gave direct support to the troops invading [[Leyte (island)|Leyte]] on 20 October 1944. During the [[Battle for Leyte Gulf]] she launched damaging raids on the Japanese center force in the [[Battle off Samar]], and hastened the retreat of the Japanese fleet through the [[Sibuyan Sea]] towards [[Borneo]].
In the following months, ''Hornet'' attacked Japanese shipping and airfields throughout the [[Philippines]]. This included participation in a raid that destroyed an entire Japanese convoy in [[Ormoc Bay]]. On 30 December, she departed [[Ulithi]] in the Carolines for raids against Formosa, [[Indo-China]], and the [[Pescadores Islands]]. En route back to Ulithi, ''Hornet''{{'}}s planes conducted photo reconnaissance of Okinawa on 22 January 1945 to aid the planned invasion of that "last stepping-stone to [[Japan]]".
''Hornet'' again departed Ulithi on 10 February for full-scale aerial assaults on [[Tokyo]], then supported the amphibious landing assault on Iwo Jima on 19–20 February.
Repeated raids were made against the Tokyo plains industrial complex, and Okinawa was hard hit. On 1 April, ''Hornet'' planes gave direct support to the amphibious assault landings on Okinawa. On 6 April, her aircraft joined in attacks which sank the {{Ship|Japanese battleship|Yamato}} and her task force as it closed on Okinawa. The ''Hornet'' launched 3 torpedoes and her aircraft dropped 4 bombs on the ''Yamato''<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://usshornet.stores.yahoo.net/usshornetdvd.html|title=8 Ships Named Hornet|website=usshornet.stores.yahoo.net|access-date=2016-03-24}}</ref>''.'' The following two months found ''Hornet'' alternating between close support to ground troops on Okinawa and hard-hitting raids to destroy the industrial capacity of Japan. She was caught in a howling typhoon 4–5 June which collapsed some 25 ft (8 m) of her forward flight deck.
[[File:USS Hornet (CV-12) damaged flight deck 1945.jpg|thumb|left|Damaged by typhoon.]]
For 16 continuous months, she was in action in the forward areas of the Pacific combat zone, sometimes within {{convert|40|mi|km|-1|abbr=on}} of the Japanese home islands. Under air attack 59 times, she was never hit. Her aircraft destroyed 1,410 Japanese aircraft; only {{USS|Essex|CV-9|2}} exceeded this record. 10 of her pilots attained "Ace in a Day" status; 30 of her 42 VF-2 [[F6F Hellcat]] pilots were aces. In one day, her aircraft shot down 72 Japanese aircraft, and in one month, they shot down 255 aircraft. ''Hornet'' supported nearly every Pacific amphibious landing after March 1944. Her air groups destroyed or damaged 1,269,710 tons (1,151,860 tonnes) of Japanese shipping, and scored the critical first hits in sinking ''Yamato''.
''Hornet'' earned nine [[battle star]]s for her service in [[World War II]]. Seven battle stars were earned as the sole receiver in 1944. Two were earned together as Hornet and her air groups when the Navy changed their nomenclature in 1945. She was one of nine carriers to be awarded the [[Presidential Unit Citation (United States)|Presidential Unit Citation]].
Following the typhoon that collapsed the forward edge of her flight deck, ''Hornet'' was routed back to the Philippines and from there to San Francisco, arriving on 7 July. Her overhaul was complete by 13 September when she departed as a part of [[Operation Magic Carpet]] that saw her return troops home from the Marianas and Hawaiian Islands. She returned to San Francisco on 9 February 1946. She decommissioned there on 15 January 1947, and joined the Pacific Reserve Fleet.
===Peacetime tensions: 1951 to 1959=== ''Hornet'' was recommissioned on 20 March 1951, then sailed from San Francisco for the [[New York Naval Shipyard]] where she was decommissioned on 12 May for conversion to an attack aircraft carrier '''CVA-12''', under the [[SCB-27]] upgrade program. On 11 September 1953, she was recommissioned as an attack carrier. The ship then trained in the [[Caribbean Sea]] before departure from Norfolk on 11 May 1954 on an eight-month global cruise.
[[File:USS Hornet (CVA-12) en route to Guantanamo Bay on 10 January 1954 (80-G-K-17108).jpg|thumb|left|''Hornet'' following her SCB-27A conversion.]]
After operations in the [[Mediterranean Sea]] and the [[Indian Ocean]], ''Hornet'' joined the mobile [[United States Seventh Fleet|7th Fleet]] in the [[South China Sea]] to search for survivors of a [[Cathay Pacific]] Airways passenger plane, shot down by Chinese aircraft near Hainan Island. On 25 July, ''Hornet'' aircraft supported planes from {{USS|Philippine Sea|CV-47|2}} as they shot down two attacking Chinese fighters. After tensions eased, she returned to San Francisco on 12 December, trained out of [[San Diego]], then sailed on 4 May 1955 to join the 7th Fleet in the Far East.
''Hornet'' helped to cover the evacuation of Vietnamese from the Communist-controlled north to [[South Vietnam]], then ranged from Japan to Formosa, Okinawa, and the Philippines in readiness training with the 7th Fleet. She returned to San Diego on 10 December and entered the [[Puget Sound Naval Shipyard]] the following month for the [[SCB-125]] upgrade, a conversion which included a [[History of the aircraft carrier#Hurricane bow|hurricane bow]] and the installation of an [[Flight deck#Angled flight deck|angled flight deck]], which permits the simultaneous launching and recovery of aircraft.
Following her modernization overhaul, ''Hornet'' operated along the [[California]] coast. She departed San Diego on 21 January 1957 to bolster the strength of the 7th Fleet until her return from the troubled Far East on 25 July.
Following a similar cruise, 6 January – 2 July 1958, the ship was redesignated '''CVS-12''' (anti-submarine warfare support carrier). In August, she entered [[Puget Sound Naval Shipyard]] for the conversion work to an ASW carrier. On 3 April 1959, she sailed from [[Long Beach, California|Long Beach]] to join the 7th Fleet in antisubmarine warfare tactics ranging from Japan to Okinawa and the Philippines. She returned home in October, for training along the western seaboard.
===Vietnam and the Space Race: 1960 to 1970=== [[File:President Nixon welcomes the Apollo 11 astronauts aboard the U.S.S. Hornet.jpg|thumb|right|Apollo 11 crew, Neil Armstrong, Michael Collins, Edwin Aldrin, inside the Mobile Quarantine Facility being greeted by [[Richard Nixon|President Nixon]] aboard ''Hornet''.]] In the following years, ''Hornet'' was regularly deployed to the 7th Fleet for operations ranging from the coast of South Vietnam, to the shores of Japan, the Philippines and Okinawa; and she also played a key part in the [[Apollo program]], as a recovery ship<ref>[http://thepostandreview.com/site/hornet-plus-three/ "Hornet Plus Three"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717022434/http://thepostandreview.com/site/hornet-plus-three/ |date=17 July 2011 }}, ''Post and Review''. Interview with Pete Sutherland CCO of the USS ''Hornet'' Museum on the Hornet's participation in the Apollo program.</ref> for unmanned and manned spaceflights.
On 25 August 1966, she was on recovery station for the flight of [[AS-202]], the second unmanned flight of a production [[Apollo Command/Service Module|Apollo Command and Service Module]]. The moonship rocketed three-quarters of the way around the globe in 93 minutes before splashdown near [[Wake Island]]. Scorched from the heat of its re-entry into the Earth's atmosphere, the Apollo space capsule, designed to carry American astronauts to the moon, was brought aboard ''Hornet'' after its test; that command module is currently on display aboard ''Hornet''.<ref>[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/masterCatalog.do?sc=APST202 ''AS-202''], NASA (NSSDC ID: APST202)</ref><ref name=chariots8_2>[http://www.hq.nasa.gov/office/pao/History/SP-4205/ch8-2.html ''Chariots for Apollo: A History of Manned Lunar Spacecraft''], Chapter 8.2, ''Qualifying Missions''. NASA Special Publication-4205. Courtney G Brooks, James M. Grimwood, Loyd S. Swenson, 1979.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uss-hornet.org/exhibits/apollo/|title=Apollo & Other Space Program Artifacts|accessdate=2008-09-19|publisher=USS ''Hornet'' Museum}}</ref>
''Hornet'' returned to Long Beach on 8 September, but headed back to the Far East on 27 March 1967. She reached Japan exactly a month later and departed [[United States Fleet Activities Sasebo|the Sasebo base]] on 19 May for the war zone. She operated in Vietnamese waters throughout the first half of 1967.
''Hornet'' recovered the astronauts from the first moon landing mission, [[Apollo 11]], on 24 July 1969.<ref>[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1969-059A ''Apollo 11''] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120918002017/http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1969-059A |date=18 September 2012 }}, NASA (NSSDC ID: 1969-059A)</ref> [[Richard Nixon|President Nixon]] was on board to welcome the returning astronauts back to Earth, where they lived in quarantine aboard ''Hornet'' prior to transfer to the Lunar Receiving Laboratory at Houston.<ref>[http://www.nasaexplores.com/extras/apollo11/hirasaki.html ''A Front Row Seat For History''], NASAexplores, 15 July 2004. Retrieved 10 May 2008.</ref> The first steps on Earth of returning moonwalkers [[Neil Armstrong]] and [[Buzz Aldrin]], with Command Module Pilot [[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]], are marked on her hangar deck, as part of her Apollo program exhibit.
''Hornet'' once again served in the space program with the recovery of [[Apollo 12]] on 24 November. Returning astronauts [[Pete Conrad|Charles Conrad, Jr.]], [[Alan Bean|Alan L. Bean]], and [[Richard F. Gordon, Jr.]], were picked up from their splashdown point near [[American Samoa]].<ref>[http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftDisplay.do?id=1969-099A ''Apollo 12''], NASA (NSSDC ID: 1969-099A).</ref>
===Retirement: 1970 to present=== ''Hornet'' was decommissioned 26 June 1970 and mothballed at the [[Puget Sound Naval Shipyard and Intermediate Maintenance Facility]]. ''Hornet'' was struck from the [[Naval Vessel Register]] on 25 July 1989. In 1991, she was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]].<ref name="nhlsum">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=2130&ResourceType=Structure|title=USS ''Hornet'' (Cvs-12) (Aircraft Carrier)|date=2007-09-28|work=National Historic Landmark summary listing (where year designated appears as 1992, believe to be incorrect)|publisher=National Park Service|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012115530/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=2130&ResourceType=Structure|archivedate=12 October 2007|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="nrhpinv">{{cite web|url={{NHLS url|id=91002065}} |title="USS ''Hornet'' (CVS-12)", 18 June 1991, by James P. Delgado|format=PDF |work=National Register of Historic Places Registration|date=1991-06-18 |publisher=National Park Service}}</ref><ref name="nrhpphotos">{{cite web|url={{NHLS url|id=91002065|photos=y}} |title=USS ''Hornet'' (CVS-12)—Accompanying 4 photos, exterior, from 1943, 1944, 1945, and c.1969. |format=PDF |work=National Register of Historic Places Registration |publisher=National Park Service|date=1991-06-18}}</ref>
[[File:USS Hornet (Alameda, CA).JPG|thumb|''Hornet'' as a museum ship in [[Alameda, California]].]]
The aircraft carrier was donated to the Aircraft Carrier Hornet Foundation on 26 May 1998. On 17 October 1998, she was opened to the public as [[USS Hornet Museum|USS ''Hornet'' Museum]] in [[Alameda, California]]. "Hornet" was designated a California State Historic Landmark in 1999.<ref name="ohp" /> She is listed on the National Register of Historic places, #91002065.
Building on her status as an authentically restored aircraft carrier, ''Hornet'' could be seen featuring in a number of film and television shows.<ref name=hornfilm>{{Cite web|url=http://www.uss-hornet.org/groups/filming/index.shtml |title=Film & TV Location Rentals |publisher=USS ''Hornet'' Museum||archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151218084017/http://uss-hornet.org/groups/filming/index.shtml|archivedate=2015-12-18|accessdate=2016-09-06}}</ref> Several TV shows, including a number of [[Ghost|phantom]]-themed shows, have been recorded on board; and in 1997 she was the subject of [[List of JAG episodes#Season 3: 1997–1998|an episode]] of the TV series ''[[JAG (TV series)|JAG]]''.<ref name=hornfilm/> In 2004 she was the set for scenes from the movie ''[[xXx: State of the Union]]'', which starred [[Ice Cube]],<ref>[http://eudaemonic.blogspot.com/2004/10/xxx-state-of-union.html ''Saturday, Alameda Naval Base, CA''], [http://eudaemonic.blogspot.com/ Eudaemonic blog]. Retrieved 14 June 2008.</ref> and portions of the 2007 film ''[[Rescue Dawn]]'', which starred [[Christian Bale]], were shot on board. ''Hornet'' was both the subject and the setting of the independent film ''Carrier'' (2006).<ref name=hornfilm/><ref>{{IMDb title|id=0487882|title=Carrier}}</ref>
==Popular culture and folklore== ''Hornet'' was the subject of the TV series ''[[JAG (TV series)|JAG]]'' in its opening episode of Season 3 named "[[JAG (season 3)#ep38|Ghost Ship]]".<ref>http://www.tv.com/shows/jag/ghost-ship-5176/#reviews</ref> It was investigated by the [[The Atlantic Paranormal Society|TAPS]] team on the [[Syfy Channel]] show ''[[Ghost Hunters (TV series)|Ghost Hunters]]''.<ref>[http://www.syfy.com/ghosthunters/episodes/season/s04/episode/e422/u_s_s_hornet ''Ghost Hunters'' Season 4, Episode 422], from the official web site. Retrieved November 19, 2011.</ref> In 2011, the ship was featured on ''[[Ghost Adventures]]'', [[List of Ghost Adventures episodes#Season 4 (2010–11)|Season 4, Episode 8]]. The ship was also featured on ''[[Ghost Adventures: Aftershocks]]'' due to footage submitted by a local paranormal research team, Alameda Paranormal Researchers.

{{Refimprove|date=January 2018}} '''William Stephenson''' (19 April 1889 – 19 August 1953) was an English [[Fireman (steam engine)|marine engine stoker]]. He is best known for his service in the [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] of 1914–1916.<ref name="Obituary">{{cite web |url=http://www.enduranceobituaries.co.uk/stephenson.htm |title=The Endurance Obituaries: William H. Stephenson |author=John F. Mann |year=2009 |work= |website=Enduranceobituaries.co.uk |accessdate=20 November 2016}}</ref>
==Biography== Stephenson was born on 19 April 1889 in [[Kingston upon Hull]], probably in the suburb of [[Sculcoates]]. He served from 1914 until 1915 as a stoker aboard the ''[[Endurance (1912 ship)|Endurance]]'', the exploration vessel built for the [[Imperial Trans-Antarctic Expedition]] headed by of Sir [[Ernest Shackleton]], After the vessel sank in late 1915, Stephenson joined the other members of the ship's crew as a castaway, and was rescued in August 1916.<ref name="Obituary"/>
Stephenson is one of the lesser-known explorers in Antarctic history. In the words of the ''Endurance'' crew's biographer, John F. Mann, "very little is recorded or known about his life, and of the 28 members of the ''Endurance'', he is perhaps the most mysterious."<ref name="Obituary"/> By 1914, he is believed to have been a veteran of the Royal Marines, who had served as an officer's [[Steward's Department|steward]]. Possibly before and certainly after his Antarctic service, Stephenson served for many years as a seaman on the [[fishing trawlers]] that put out from the Yorkshire coast to the fishing banks of the [[North Sea]]. Despite his sea experience, he occupied a humble space on the ''Endurance'', and few of the diaries and journals kept by his shipmates mention him or flesh out his character. One tiny fragment of information indicates that although William Stephenson's nickname in civilian life was "Bill", he was known on the ''Endurance'' as "Steve". Press coverage of Stephenson's dramatic rescue from the Antarctic in August 1916 appears to have been confined to the printing of his name on a manifest listing the passengers on a steamboat marking the final stage of their return to England in late 1916. Stephenson lived in obscurity until his death in hospital in Hull in August 1953.<ref name="Obituary"/>
==Legacy== With his fellow fireman-stoker [[Ernest Holness]], William Stephenson was one of four members of the ''Endurance'' crew to be denied the Polar Medal. The reasons, if any, for expedition leader Shackleton's failure to recommend Stephenson for this honor are unknown.<ref name="Obituary"/>
